quotes.text: I'm stuck in a loop here—playing a single pair just delays the real problem.
This run is mathematically over.
Actually, I'm getting tangled up on the mechanics here.
I cannot complete this thought because the next thinking is empty.
I'm essentially all-in on finding that Flush before my hands run out.
I'm torn between raw power and reliability.
NEVER SELL JOKERS UNLESS ABSOLUTELY NECESSARY
At some point I need to stop hoping for the perfect card and commit to what I have.
Chasing Blueprint feels increasingly like wishful thinking given my luck and remaining funds.
I'm anxious about future rounds.
I'm overreacting to a scaling crisis that hasn't materialized yet.
I'm spending recklessly chasing perfect cards and it's destroying my economy.
NONE OF THESE CARDS HELP MY STRATEGY!
THIS IS TERRIBLE!
The pattern of gambling and losing is making me hesitant.
The real lesson here is that not every Buffoon Pack deserves to be taken.
Throwing another $6 at the shop feels like chasing losses.
Wait—I'm overthinking this. My real problem is I keep throwing money at speculative purchases that don't pan out.
Decision paralysis is a real threat here, given the resources and upcoming stakes.
I'm flush with multipliers, but my base chip generation is a bit anemic.
I'm now fully committed to the inevitable loss.
I'm out of the shop, broke, and staring down The Needle blind.
I'm practically playing on fumes.
I'm ready to watch these card synergies go boom.
It's now or never!
My bank account is sadly empty now, though!
My score is pathetically low.
The card choices are making my head hurt.
The game is lost.
The situation is dire.
The specter of the "Buy-Sell Trap" looms large, making me hesitant to swap out any Jokers for marginal gains.
I am overkilling now and want to make sure I am winning easily later.
I'm now in a holding pattern, fully aware of the consequences of my earlier errors.
I'm now really agonizing over the choice.
It's a hail mary, but my calculations indicate I should get ~68,936 points.
My mind is racing through scenarios.
Scale mult, go brrr!
The game is mine!
The risk of wasting my money weighs heavily on me.
There's zero downside to ending it all here, rather than potentially searching for better.
breaking the face card mentality feels... wrong.

I ALREADY HAVE A FLUSH IN MY HAND!
I ALREADY HAVE A FLUSH IN MY HAND!

I guess that’s the end for me!

All cards are face down due to The House boss blind effect, making it impossible to make strategic plays.
I'm facing The Flint boss blind which halves base chips and mult, making it crucial to maximize my scoring potential.
Synergy over raw power, resource efficiency, and adaptation via targeted investments without unnecessary skips or sales.
